[[Solaris (operating system)|Solaris]] until v. 10.11 | engine = [[Presto (layout engine)|Presto]] | language = 51 languages{{cite web |url=http://www.opera.com/download/languagefiles/|title=Opera browser language files|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=12 April 2011}} | status = Active | genre = [[Web browser]] and [[Internet suite]] | programming language = [[C++]]{{cite web|url=http://www.lextrait.com/Vincent/implementations.html|title=The Programming Languages Beacon, v10.3|first=Vincent|last=Lextrait|month=July|year=2010|accessdate=5 September 2010}} | license = [[Proprietary software|Proprietary]] ([[Freeware]]) with [[open source]] components | website = {{URL|http://www.opera.com/}} }} '''Opera''' is a [[web browser]] and [[Internet suite]] developed by [[Opera Software]] with over 200 million users worldwide.http://www.opera.com/media/finance/2011/2Q11_press_release.pdf The browser handles common [[Internet]]-related tasks such as displaying [[web sites]], sending and receiving [[e-mail]] messages, managing contacts, [[online chat|chatting]] on [[Internet Relay Chat|IRC]], downloading files via [[BitTorrent (protocol)|BitTorrent]], and reading [[web feed]]s. Opera is offered free of charge for [[personal computer]]s and [[mobile phone]]s. Opera does not come packaged with any [[Desktop computer|desktop]] [[operating system]]. However, it is the most popular desktop browser in some countries, such as [[Ukraine]].[http://gs.statcounter.com/#browser-UA-monthly-201011-201011-bar] [[Opera Mini]], which is the [[Usage share of web browsers#StatCounter Mobile|most popular]][http://gs.statcounter.com/#mobile_browser-ww-monthly-201011-201011-bar] [[mobile web browser]] as of May 2011, has been chosen as the default integrated web browser in several [[mobile handset]]s {{cite news|title=Opera Mini Is the Most Popular Web Browser|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/Opera-Mini-Is-the-Most-Popular-Web-Browser-54458.shtml|accessdate=30 May 2011|newspaper=http://news.softpedia.com/|date=11 May 2007}} {{cite news|title=Opera Mini browser now comes preloaded on Samsung Galaxy S Smartphone|url=http://www.littleabout.com/Techno/opera-mini-samsung-galaxy-s-smartphone/98570/|accessdate=30 May 2011|newspaper=http://www.littleabout.com/|date=10 Dec 2010}} {{cite news|title=Opera Mini to be default Web browser on new feature phones|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/TECH/mobile/02/14/opera.mini.brew/index.html|accessdate=30 May 2011|newspaper=CNN|date=15 February 2011}} by their respective manufacturers. Features include [[tabbed browsing]], [[page zooming]], [[mouse gesture]]s, and an integrated [[download manager]]. Its security features include built-in [[phishing]] and [[malware]] protection, [[Transport Layer Security|SSL/TLS]] [[encryption]] when browsing [[HTTPS]] websites, and the ability to easily {{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} delete private data such as [[HTTP cookie]]s. Opera is known for originating many features later adopted by other web browsers.{{cite web|url=http://arstechnica.com/software/reviews/2009/09/first-look-opera-10-faster-with-new-features.ars|title=First look: Opera 10 faster with new features|accessdate=5 September 2010|last=Reimer|first=Jeremy|date=1 September 2009|publisher=Ars Technica}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wired.com/epicenter/2008/12/opera-10-previe/|title=Opera 10 Preview Continues Pioneering Web Standards Support|accessdate=5 September 2010|last=Gilbertson|first=Scott|date=4 December 2008|publisher=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired Magazine]]}} Opera runs on a variety of personal computer [[operating system]]s, including [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Mac OS X|Mac OS X]], [[Linux]], and [[FreeBSD]]. Editions of Opera are available for devices using the [[Maemo]], [[BlackBerry]], [[Symbian]], [[Windows Mobile]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], and [[iPhone OS|iOS]] operating systems, as well as [[Java ME]]-enabled devices.{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/14/technology/14opera.html|title=Apple Lets Opera Browser Use Own Software on iPhone|first=Kevin|last=O'Brien|date=13 April 2010|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=5 September 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.opera.com/download/index.dml?custom=yes|title=Download Opera Web Browser|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=5 September 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.opera.com/mobile/download/blackberry/|title=Download Opera Web Browser|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=5 September 2010}} Approximately 120 million mobile phones have been shipped with Opera.{{cite web|url=http://www.opera.com/smw/|title=State of the Mobile Web report|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=5 September 2010|quote=Opera Mobile has shipped on more than 120 million mobile phones so far.}} Opera is the only commercial web browser available for the [[Nintendo DS]] and [[Wii]] gaming systems. Some television [[set-top box]]es use Opera. [[Adobe Systems]] has licensed Opera technology for use in the [[Adobe Creative Suite]].{{cite press release|url=http://www.opera.com/press/releases/2005/04/04/|title=Powered by Opera: Opera Integrated with Adobe Creative Suite 2|publisher=Opera Software|date=4 April 2005|accessdate=5 September 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://operawatch.com/news/2007/05/dreamweaver-uses-operas-small-screen-rendering-technology-to-preview-webpages-for-mobile-phones.html|title=Dreamweaver uses Operaâs Small-Screen Rendering technology to preview webpages for mobile phones|last=Goldman|first=Daniel|publisher=Opera Watch|date=3 May 2007|accessdate=5 September 2010}} ==History== [[File:HÃ¥kon Wium Lie.jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[HÃ¥kon Wium Lie]], [[chief technical officer]] of the [[Opera Software]] company and co-creator of the [[CSS]] [[web standards|web standard]]]] {{Main|History of the Opera web browser}} {{See also|Opera Mobile#History|Opera Mini#History|Nintendo DS & DSi Browser#Launch|Internet Channel#History|Opera Software#History}} Opera began in 1994 as a research project at [[Telenor]], the largest Norwegian telecommunications company. In 1995, it branched out into a separate company named [[Opera Software]] [[Allmennaksjeselskap|ASA]].{{cite web|url=http://www.opera.com/company/|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20071203140601/http://www.opera.com/company/about/|title=About Opera|publisher=Opera Software|archivedate=3 December 2007|accessdate=5 September 2010}} Opera was first released publicly with version 2.0 in 1996,{{cite web|url=http://www.foxkeh.com/downloads/history/history-original.pdf|format=PDF|title=Affiliated Organization of Firefox and Mozilla|publisher=[[Mozilla Foundation]]|work=Mozilla Japan|year=2006|accessdate=5 September 2010}} which only ran on [[Microsoft Windows]].{{cite web|url=http://www.opera.com/company/history/|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20071123104427/http://www.opera.com/company/about/milestones/|title=Milestones|publisher=Opera Software|archivedate=23 November 2007|accessdate=13 January 2011|year=2007}} In an attempt to capitalize on the emerging market for Internet-connected handheld devices, a project to port Opera to mobile device [[Platform (computing)|platforms]] was started in 1998. Opera 4.0, released in 2000, included a new cross-platform core that facilitated creation of editions of Opera for multiple [[operating system]]s and [[Platform (computing)|platforms]].{{cite web|url=http://www.markschenk.com/opera/history.html|title=Opera browser version history|last=Schenk|first=Mark|year=2010|accessdate=5 September 2010}}{{dead link|date=August 2011}} Up to this point, Opera was [[trialware]] and had to be purchased after the trial period ended. Version 5.0 (released in 2000) saw the end of this requirement. Instead, Opera became [[Adware|ad-sponsored]], displaying advertisements to users who had not paid for it.{{cite news|url=http://www.theregister.co.uk/2000/12/06/opera_browser_goes_free/|title=Opera browser goes free with version 5.0 launch|last=Lettice|first=John|publisher=The Register|date=6 December 2000|accessdate=5 September 2010}} Later versions of Opera gave the user the choice of seeing [[banner ad]]s or targeted text advertisements from [[Google]]. With version 8.5 (released in 2005) the advertisements were removed entirely and primary financial support for the browser came through revenue from Google (which is by contract Opera's default search engine).{{cite news|url=http://www.searchenginejournal.com/opera-goes-free-with-help-from-google/2227/|title=Opera Goes Free with Help from Google|last=Baker|first=Loren|publisher=Search Engine Journal|date=20 September 2005|accessdate=5 September 2010}} Among the new features introduced in version 9.1 (released in 2006) was fraud protection using technology from [[GeoTrust]], a [[digital certificate]] provider, and [[PhishTank]], an organization that tracks known [[phishing]] web sites.{{cite web|url=http://operawatch.com/news/2006/12/opera-91-is-out-with-fraud-protection.html|title=Opera 9.1 is out with Fraud Protection|last=Goldman|first=Daniel|publisher=Opera Watch|date=18 December 2006|accessdate=5 September 2010}} This feature was further improved and expanded in version 9.5, when GeoTrust was replaced with [[Netcraft]], and malware protection from [[Haute Secure]] was added.{{cite web|url=http://my.opera.com/desktopteam/blog/2008/06/06/malware-protection|title=Malware protection|last=Kleinhout|first=Huib|publisher=Opera Software|work=Opera Desktop Team|date=6 June 2008|accessdate=5 September 2010}} Also in 2006, editions of Opera were made and released for Nintendo's [[Nintendo DS|DS]] and [[Wii]] gaming systems.{{cite press release|url=http://www.opera.com/press/releases/2006/02/15/|title=Giving gamers two windows to the Web: The Opera Browser for Nintendo DS|publisher=Opera Software|date=15 February 2006|accessdate=5 September 2010}}{{cite press release|url=http://www.opera.com/press/releases/2007/06/08/|title=Nintendo DS Browser available to North American market|publisher=Opera Software|date=8 June 2007|accessdate=5 September 2010}}{{cite press release|url=http://www.opera.com/press/releases/2006/05/10/|title=A Web Revolution in the Living room: Opera partners with Nintendo to put browser on the Wii game console|publisher=Opera Software|date=10 May 2006|accessdate=5 September 2010 }}{{cite press release|url=http://www.opera.com/press/releases/2006/12/22/|title=Play with the Web: Opera browser now available for download on Wii|publisher=Opera Software|date=22 December 2006 |accessdate=5 September 2010}} Opera for the Wii, called the [[Internet Channel]], was free to download from its release on 12 April 2007{{cite press release|url=http://www.opera.com/press/releases/2007/04/12/|title=Get to Know the Web on Wii: Full Version of Wii Internet Channel Powered by Opera Available for Free Download|publisher=Opera Software|date=12 April 2007|accessdate=5 September 2010}} until 30 June 2007. After that date, Wii users had to pay 500 [[Wii Points]] (about [[US$]]5{{cite web|url=http://www.amazon.com/dp/B000IMYL0U|title=Wii 2000 Points Card|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=5 September 2010}}) to download it.{{cite news|url=http://www.1up.com/do/newsStory?cId=3160583|title=Reminder: Wii Internet Channel Free 'til June 30|last=Hayward|first=Andrew|publisher=[[Ziff Davis]]|work=[[1UP.com]]|date=26 June 2007|accessdate=5 September 2010}} As of 2 September 2009, it is again free to download. Users who previously paid to download are offered a NES game of their choice of the same value.{{cite web|url=http://www.nintendo.com/wii/channels/internetchannel|title=Internet Channel|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|year=2010|accessdate=5 September 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://wii.kombo.com/article.php?artid=14757|title=Nintendo Updates Internet Channel: Free to Download, NES Rebate, and More|date=1 September 2009|accessdate=5 September 2010|first=David|last=Oxford|publisher=Kombo.com}}{{dead link|date=August 2011}} The [[Nintendo DS & DSi Browser|Nintendo DS Browser]] is not free; it is sold as a physical DS [[game cartridge]]. The [[DSi]] has an Internet Channel that can be downloaded for free from the DSi shop.{{cite web|url=http://www.amazon.com/dp/B000OAO494|title=Nintendo DS Lite Browser|publisher=Amazon.com|accessdate=5 September 2010}} A new JavaScript engine called Carakan, after the [[Javanese script]], was introduced with version 10.50.{{cite web|url=http://www.opera.com/docs/changelogs/windows/1050/|title=Opera 10.50 for Windows changelog (Final)|date=2 March 2010|publisher=[[Opera Software]]|accessdate=5 September 2010}} According to Opera Software, Carakan is more than seven times faster in [[SunSpider]] than Opera 10.10 with Futhark on Windows, which has since been more or less confirmed by other sources after its official [[Alpha test|pre-alpha]] release in December 2009.{{cite web|url=http://techie-buzz.com/opera/opera-10-5-pre-alpha-is-here-and-it-is-fast.html|title=Opera 10.5 Pre-Alpha Is Here and It Is Fast!|first=Pallab|last=De|date=22 December 2009|publisher=Techie-buzz.com|accessdate=5 September 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://lifehacker.com/5432054/opera-105-pre+alpha-is-all-about-speed-and-private-browsing|publisher=[[Lifehacker]]|title=Opera 10.5 Pre-Alpha is All About Speed (and Private Browsing)|first=Kevin|last=Purdy|date=22 December 2009|accessdate=5 September 2010}} Also introduced was Opera's vector graphics library, Vega, which handles all of the browser's rendering. This allows platform specific rendering code to be replaced with code for Vega, which makes it easier to deploy [[Cross-platform|across platforms]]; aids Opera's [[implementation]] of some advanced [[CSS3]] properties, such as backgrounds and borders; and also allows hardware acceleration with optional [[OpenGL]] and [[Direct3D]] backends.{{cite web|url=http://my.opera.com/chooseopera/blog/2009/02/05/meet-carakan-and-vega|title=Meet Carakan and Vega|last=Ãverdahl|first=Espen|publisher=Opera Software|date=5 February 2009|accessdate=5 September 2010|work=Choose Opera}} The initial release of Opera 10.50 was for Windows only, in order to allow the development team to focus on a timed release with the [[BrowserChoice.eu|EU browser ballot]] offered to [[European Economic Area]] users of [[Microsoft Windows]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/8537763.stm|title=Microsoft offers browser choices to Europeans|publisher=BBC|date=1 March 2010|accessdate=5 September 2010}} The Mac version reached final status with version 10.52 and the release of Opera 10.60 brought Windows, Mac, Linux and FreeBSD back into sync for the first time since Opera 10.10.{{cite web|url=http://my.opera.com/desktopteam/blog/2010/07/01/opera-10-60-goes-final|title=Opera 10.60 goes final|work=Opera Desktop Team|last=Kleinhout|first=Huib|date=July 1, 2010|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=September 5, 2010}} On December 16, 2010, Opera 11 was released, featuring [[Software extension|extensions]], tab stacking, visual mouse gestures, and changes to the address field.{{cite web|title=Opera features|url=http://www.opera.com/browser/features/|publisher=[[Opera ASA]]|accessdate=19 December 2010}} The new address field hides some of the whole URL, such as the [[URL#Syntax|protocol and query strings]], but this can be turned off. Within the first 24 hours of release, Opera 11 was downloaded 6.7 million times.{{cite web|url=http://my.opera.com/chooseopera/blog/2010/12/17/what-a-day|title=What a day|publisher=my.opera.com|date=2010-12-17|format=blog}} ==Features== {{Main|Features of the Opera web browser}} {{See also|Opera Mobile#Features|Opera Mini#Features|Nintendo DS & DSi Browser#Features|Internet Channel#Features}} As of version 10.5, Opera features a new JavaScript engine, as well as a new [[vector graphics]] library, which together significantly increase Opera's overall rendering speed.{{cite web|url=http://labs.opera.com/news/2009/12/22/|title=Opera 10.5 pre-alpha for Labs|work=Opera Labs|publisher=Opera Software|first=Roberto|last=Mateu|date=1 January 2010|accessdate=5 September 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://my.opera.com/desktopteam/blog/2009/12/22/from-all-of-us-to-all-of-you|title=From all of us to all of you|first=Huib|last=Kleinhout|publisher=Opera Software|work=Opera Desktop Team|date=22 December 2009|accessdate=5 September 2010}} Opera includes built-in [[tabbed browsing]], [[Ad filtering|ad blocking]], fraud protection, a [[download manager]] and [[BitTorrent (protocol)|BitTorrent]] client, a search bar, and a [[web feed]] [[feed aggregator|aggregator]]. Opera also comes with an [[e-mail]] client called [[Opera Mail]] and an [[IRC]] [[Online chat|chat]] client built in.{{cite web|url=http://www.opera.com/browser/|title=Opera browser: Features|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=5 September 2010}} Opera includes a "Speed Dial" feature, which allows the user to add up to 25 links (or more, by editing the speeddial.ini file) shown in thumbnail form in a page displayed when a new tab is opened. [[Thumbnail]]s of the linked pages are automatically generated and used for visual recognition on the Speed Dial page or can be modified using [http://miya2000.up.seesaa.net/opera/idg/dial_generator.html Opera Image Dial Generator]. Once set up, this feature allows the user to more easily navigate to the selected web pages.{{cite web|url=http://arstechnica.com/old/content/2007/04/opera-releases-9-2-browser-adds-speed-dial.ars|title=Opera releases 9.2 browser, adds "Speed Dial"|last=Reimer|first=Jeremy|publisher=Ars Technica|date=12 April 2007|accessdate=5 September 2010}} Opera supports [[Opera Widgets]], small web applications that start from within Opera. Alongside Widgets, "User JavaScript" may be used to add custom JavaScript to web pages. [[Greasemonkey]] support is limited, and there is no interface to manage scripts or toggle 'Greasemonkey-on' functionality. Opera is extensible in a third way via [[Plug-in (computing)|plug-ins]], relatively small programs that add specific functions to the browser,{{cite web|url=http://www.opera.com/docs/plugins/|title=Plug-ins|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=5 September 2010}} and as of Opera 11, third-party extensions. However, Opera limits what plug-ins can do. ===Usability and accessibility=== {| style="background:#f9f9f9; border:1px solid #aaa; float:right; margin:0.5em 0 0.8em 1.4em; width:50ex;" ! colspan="3" style="font-size:132%; padding-bottom:1ex;" | Sample mouse gestures in Opera |- | [[File:Opera back mouse gesture.svg|Opera back mouse gesture.svg]] || '''Back:''' hold down right mouse button, move mouse left, and release. Alternative: hold the right button down and click the left button |- | [[File:Opera forward mouse gesture.svg|Opera forward mouse gesture.svg]] | style="padding-right:1em" | '''Forward:''' hold down right mouse button, move mouse right, and release. Alternative: hold the left button down and click the right button |- | [[File:Opera new tab mouse gesture.svg|Opera new tab mouse gesture.svg]] || '''New tab:''' hold down right mouse button, move mouse down, and release. Clicking a link with the middle mouse button produces a similar effect, but the new tab is opened in the background instead of becoming the active tab. |} Opera was designed with a commitment to [[computer accessibility]] for users who have visual or motor impairments. As a [[multimodal browser]], it also caters to a wide variety of personal preferences in the user interface. It is possible to control nearly every aspect of the browser using only the [[Computer keyboard|keyboard]],{{cite web|url=http://www.opera.com/browser/tutorials/nomouse/|title=Use Opera without a Mouse|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=5 September 2010}} and the default [[keyboard shortcut]]s can be modified to suit the user.{{cite web|url=http://tntluoma.com/30days/day-16-sessions/|title=Day 16: Sessions|work=30 Days to becoming an Opera8 Lover|date=25 May 2005|accessdate=5 September 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://my.opera.com/csant/blog/2007/06/11/emacs-keyboard-bindings-2|title=emacs keyboard bindings - 2|last=Santambrogio|first=Claudio|work=csant/log at [[My Opera]]|publisher=Opera Software|date=11 June 2007|accessdate=5 September 2010}} It is the only major browser to include support for [[spatial navigation]]. Opera also includes support for [[mouse gesture]]s,{{cite news |url=http://news.cnet.com/2100-1023-960408.html|title=Building a better computer mouse|first=Evan|last=Hansen|publisher=[[CNET.com|CNET News]]|date=2 October 2002|accessdate=5 September 2010}} patterns of mouse movement that trigger browser actions such as "back" or "refresh".{{cite web|url=http://www.opera.com/browser/tutorials/gestures/|title=Mouse Gestures in Opera|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=5 September 2010}} [[Page zooming]] allows text, [[image]]s and other content such as [[Adobe Flash Player]], [[Java platform]] and [[Scalable Vector Graphics]] to be increased or decreased in size (20% to 1,000%) to help those with impaired vision. The user may also specify the fonts and colors for web pages, and even override the page's [[CSS]] styling as well. This can be useful for making sites appear in [[high contrast]] or in more readable fonts.{{cite web|url=http://www.opera.com/docs/usercss/index.dml|title=Opera: User CSS â Accessibility Layout|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=5 September 2010}} [[Voice control]], co-developed with [[IBM]], allows control of the browser without the use of a keyboard or mouse.{{cite web|url=http://www.extremetech.com/article2/0,3973,414251,00.asp|title=IBM, Opera To Develop "Multimode" Browser|publisher=Ziff Davis|work=[[ExtremeTech]]|date=24 July 2002|accessdate=5 September 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.webstandards.org/2004/03/26/opera-ibm-voice/|title=Opera, IBM voice|last=Koltz|first=Holly Marie|publisher=[[Web Standards Project]]|date=26 March 2004|accessdate=5 September 2010}} It can also read aloud pages and marked text. [[Opera Turbo]] is a feature intended for slower [[internet]] connections; when enabled, Opera's [[Server (computing)|server]]s act as a [[Proxy server|proxy]] which compresses the requested web page by up to 80% before sending it to the user. This process reduces the total size of the data being sent, and thus shortens the amount of time necessary for the page to load. This technique is also used in [[#Mobile phones|Opera Mini]].{{cite web|url=http://www.opera.com/business/solutions/turbo/|title=Opera Turbo|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=5 September 2010}}{{dead link|date=August 2011}} ===Privacy and security=== Opera has several security features visible to the end user. One is the option to delete private data, such as [[HTTP cookie]]s, the browsing history, and the [[cache]], with the click of a button. This lets users erase personal data after browsing from a shared computer.{{cite web|url=http://tntluoma.com/30days/delete-private-data/|title=Delete Private Data|work=30 Days to becoming an Opera8 Lover|date=23 September 2005|accessdate=5 September 2010}} When visiting a secure web site, Opera encrypts data using either [[Secure Sockets Layer|SSL]] 3 or [[Transport Layer Security|TLS]],{{cite web|url=http://labs.opera.com/news/2006/05/16/|title=What's new in the SSL/TLS engine of Opera 9?|last=Pettersen|first=Yngve|publisher=Opera Software|date=16 May 2006|accessdate=5 September 2010|work=Opera Labs}}{{cite web|url=http://www.securityteacher.com/2006/02/18/security-in-opera-browser-a-brief-glance/|last=Pankov|first=Igor|title=Security in Opera Browser: A Brief Glance|publisher=Agnitum Ltd|date=18 February 2006|accessdate=5 September 2010}} both of which are highly secure encryption protocols. It then adds information about the site's security to the [[address bar]]. It will also check the web site that is being visited against blacklists for [[phishing]] and [[malware]], and warn if it matches any of these lists. This behavior is enabled by default, but the user may opt to not make such checks automatically. If this check is disabled, the user can still check sites individually by opening a Page Info dialog.{{cite web|url=http://www.opera.com/docs/fraudprotection/|title=Opera Fraud and Malware Protection|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=5 September 2010}} The user can protect every saved password stored in Opera with a master password. This prevents malware from accessing those passwords unless the master password is known. To catch security flaws and other [[software bug]]s before they are exploited or become a serious problem, the Opera Software company maintains a public [[web form]] where users can submit bug reports.{{cite web|url=http://www.opera.com/support/bugs/|title=Reporting Bugs|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=5 September 2010}} According to [[Secunia]], a computer security service provider, the mean average of unpatched vulnerabilities in the last 365 days is 0.01. This stands in contrast to [[Internet Explorer]] (38.3), [[Firefox]] (5.77), and [[Safari (web browser)|Safari]] (1.54).{{cite web|url=http://www.webdevout.net/browser-security|title=Web browser security summary|first=David|last=Hammond|accessdate=5 September 2010|date=10 February 2009}} In January 2007, [[Asa Dotzler]] of the competing [[Mozilla Corporation]] accused the Opera Software company of downplaying information about security vulnerabilities in Opera that were fixed in December 2006. Dotzler claimed that users were not clearly informed of security vulnerabilities present in the previous version of Opera, and thus they would not realize that they needed to upgrade to the latest version or risk being exploited.{{cite news|url=http://www.internetnews.com/dev-news/article.php/3653031|title=Mozilla Takes Aim at Opera Security|last=Kerner|first=Sean Michael|publisher=[[Quinstreet]]|work=Internetnews.com|date=9 January 2007|accessdate=5 September 2010}} Opera responded to these accusations the next day.{{cite news|url=http://www.internetnews.com/dev-news/article.php/3653226|title=Opera Has Words For Mozilla|last=Kerner|first=Sean Michael|publisher=Quinstreet|work=Internetnews.com|date=10 January 2007|accessdate=5 September 2010}} ===Standards support=== Opera was one of the first browsers to support [[Cascading Style Sheets]] (CSS), now a major building block of web design.{{cite web|url=http://meyerweb.com/eric/articles/webrev/199906.html|title=CSS: If not now, when?|first=Eric|last=Meyer|authorlink=Eric Meyer|publisher=meyerweb.com|month=June|year=1999|accessdate=5 September 2010}} Today, Opera supports many [[web standards]], including CSS 2.1, [[HTML]] 4.01, [[XHTML]] 1.1, [[XHTML Basic]], [[XHTML Mobile Profile]], [[XHTML+Voice]], [[Wireless Markup Language|WML]] 2.0, [[XSLT]], [[XPath]], [[XSL-FO]], [[ECMAScript]] 3 ([[JavaScript]]), [[Document Object Model|DOM]] 2, [[XMLHttpRequest]], [[HTTP]] 1.1, [[Transport Layer Security|TLS]] 1.2,{{cite web|url=http://my.opera.com/core/blog/2009/02/25/new-in-opera-presto-2-2-tls-1-2-support|title=New in Opera Presto 2.2: TLS 1.2 Support|last=Pettersen|first=Yngve NysÃ¦ter|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=5 September 2010|work=Opera Core Concerns|date=25 February 2009}} [[Unicode]], [[SVG]] 1.1 Basic, SVG 1.1 Tiny, [[GIF89a]], [[JPEG]], and full support for [[Portable Network Graphics|PNG]], including [[alpha transparency]].{{cite web|url=http://www.opera.com/docs/specs/|title=Web Specifications Supported in Opera 9|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=5 September 2010}} Since version 9, Opera passes the [[Acid2]] test, a test of whether or not a browser properly supports certain web standards. Opera was the second or fourth web browser to pass the test (depending on opinions regarding hiding the scrollbar){{cite web|url=http://www.howtocreate.co.uk/acid/#scrollbarnotes|title=Acid 2 in major browsers â Notes about the scrollbar|first=Mark|last=Wilton-Jones|accessdate=5 September 2010}} and the first Windows browser to do so. Opera 10.5+ achieves a score of 100/100 on the [[Acid3]] test{{cite web|url=http://www.techspot.com/downloads/40-opera-for-windows.html|title=Opera 10.61.3484 for Windows|publisher=[[TechSpot]]|date=12 August 2010|accessdate=5 September 2010}} which is primarily focused on [[Document Object Model|DOM]] and [[JavaScript]] standards compliance. On [[Ecma International]]'s [[ECMAScript]] standards conformance Test 262{{cite web|url=http://test262.ecmascript.org/|title=ECMAScript test262|accessdate=May 6, 2011|publisher=EMCAScript}} (version 0.7.2), Opera version 11.10 scores 3840/10872. Lower scores are better, as the figure represents the number of failed tests out of the total number of tests. A pre-release build of Opera 12 scores 1/10927 on Test 262,{{cite web|url=http://my.opera.com/desktopteam/blog/2011/09/13/es5|title=Full ECMAScript (JavaScript) 5.1 support|accessdate=October 2, 2011|publisher=Opera Software ASA}} the one failed test being invalid. On the official CSS 2.1 test suite by standardization organization [[W3C]], Opera's rendering engine Presto passes 89,37% (77.44% out of 86.65%) of covered CSS 2.1 tests.{{cite web|url=http://www.w3.org/Style/CSS/Test/CSS2.1/20110323/reports/results.html|title=CSS 2.1 Test Suite RC6 Results|accessdate=May 31, 2011|publisher=W3C}} ===Opera Unite=== [[File:OperaUnite.svg|134px|thumb|right|Opera Unite Logo]] Opera Unite is an extensible [[software framework|framework]] that allows for several web services (referred to as "''Applications''"{{cite web|url=http://my.opera.com/desktopteam/blog/2009/09/21/unite-applications|title=Unite Apps are coming ever closer...|date=21 September 2009|accessdate=5 September 2010|publisher=Opera Software|work=Opera Desktop Team|first=Daniel|last=Aleksandersen|quote=We are re-branding Unite Services as Unite Applications in the name of simplicity}}) to be [[Host (network)|hosted]] from the user's computer, including a web server for hosting a site, file and photo sharing, a chat room, and streaming media. Opera Software has released an [[Application programming interface|API]] to create new or improved applications for the Opera Unite Platform, and many have already done so. An Opera Unite user's applications run on a domain associated with their [[My Opera]] Community account, and are accessible from any web browser. For these applications to be accessed, the computer and the Opera Browser hosting the applications must both be running. The included API uses HTML, CSS, [[client-side]] ECMAScript and a new [[server-side JavaScript]] technology with local file access and [[Persistence (computer science)|persistent storage]]. Unite Applications are packaged according to the W3C [[Widget engine#Widget draft standard|Widgets 1.0]] specification. Opera also provides a [[Vetting|vetted]] facility for developers to upload these user-created applications.{{cite web|url=http://dev.opera.com/articles/view/opera-unite-developer-primer-revisited/#uploading|accessdate=5 September 2010|title=Opera Unite developerâs primer â revisited # Publishing your Opera Unite application onto unite.opera.com|date=14 October 2009|first1=Hans S.|last1=TÃ¸mmerholt|first2=Daniel|last2=Davis|publisher=Opera Software|work=Dev.Opera}} Unite has been included standard since version 10.10.{{cite press release|url=http://www.opera.com/press/releases/2009/11/23/|title=Join Opera's journey to reinvent the Web|publisher=Opera Software|date=23 November 2009|accessdate=5 September 2010}} Opera Unite competes with services like [[Tonido]].{{cite web|url=http://my.opera.com/haavard/blog/2009/06/18/how-opera-became-a-big-company-and-started-crushing-dreams|title=How Opera became a big company and started crushing dreams|work=A Blog From Behind the Trenches on [[My Opera]]|date=18 June 2009|publisher=Opera Software|author=Haavard|accessdate=5 September 2010}} ==Other versions== In addition to the versions of Opera for [[personal computer]]s, there are versions for a variety of devices, all based on the same core,{{cite web|url=http://nontroppo.org/timer/kestrel_tests/#conclusion|title=Performance Tests for Opera 9.5: Conclusions|accessdate=6 September 2010}} with some variation in the features offered and the user interface. ===Portable version=== In Opera 11, the installer gives you the option to install the browser as a "Standalone Installation (USB)." {{cite web|url=http://www.portablefreeware.com/?id=507|title=The Portable Freeware Collection - Opera|accessdate=18 April 2011}} There are also 3rd-party portable versions of the browser available for Microsoft Windows. ===Smartphones and PDAs=== {{Main|Opera Mobile}} [[File:Nokia5800 Opera Mobile 10 1 Beta.JPG|thumb|left|210px|[[Opera Mobile]] can be used on smartphones such as the [[Nokia 5800]].]] [[Opera Mobile]] is an edition of Opera designed for [[smartphone]]s and [[personal digital assistant]]s (PDAs). The first version of Opera Mobile was released in 2000 for the [[Psion Series 7]] and [[Psion Netbook|NetBook]], with a port to the [[Windows Mobile]] platform coming in 2004.{{cite press release|url=http://www.opera.com/press/releases/2000/03/31/|title=mCommerce Now a Reality on Psion Platform|publisher=Opera Software|date=3 April 2000|accessdate=6 September 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://jp.opera.com/products/mobile/brochures/OperaMobileTimeline.pdf|format=PDF|title=Opera Mobile Timeline|publisher=Opera Software|year=2006|accessdate=6 September 2010| archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080625214351/http://jp.opera.com/products/mobile/brochures/OperaMobileTimeline.pdf| archivedate = June 25, 2008}} Today, Opera Mobile is available for a variety of devices that run Android, the Windows Mobile, [[S60 platform]], or [[UIQ]] [[operating system]]s. Users may also try Opera Mobile free.{{cite web|url=http://www.opera.com/mobile/download/?show=mobile|title=Buy Opera|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=}} Devices that use the UIQ 3 operating system, such as the [[Sony Ericsson P990]] and [[Motorola RIZR Z8]], come pre-installed with Opera Mobile, the former price of Opera Mobile being included in the price of the phone.{{cite web |url=http://www.opera.com/mobile/|title=Products featuring the Opera Mobile Browser|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=6 September 2010}} One of Opera Mobile's major features is the ability to dynamically reformat web pages to better fit the handheld's display using [[small screen rendering]] technology.{{cite press release|url=http://www.opera.com/press/releases/2004/11/23/|title=The new ERA of content rendering: Opera Introduces Fit-to-Window Technology for All Screen Sizes|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=6 September 2010|date=23 November 2004}} Alternatively, the user may use [[page zooming]] for a closer or broader look.{{cite web|url=http://www.opera.com/mobile/tutorials/s60/|title=Opera for Symbian S60|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=6 September 2010}} However, like previous versions of Opera for personal computers, Opera Mobile's [[user interface]] has come under fire for being difficult to use or customize.{{cite web|url=http://www.smartphonemag.com/cms/index.php?q=blogs/3/prelude_to_the_opera_mobile_vs_netfront|title=Post details: Prelude to the Opera Mobile vs NetFront article â profound differences between the two new Web browsers|last=Ruotsalainen|first=Werner|publisher=[[Smartphone & Pocket PC magazine]]|date=2 June 2006|accessdate=6 September 2010}}{{cite 2010}} ===Mobile phones=== {{Main|Opera Mini}} [[File:Opera mini.png|thumb|right|300px|When a user browses the web using Opera Mini, the request is sent via the [[General Packet Radio Service]] (GPRS) to one of the Opera Software company's servers, which retrieves the web page, processes it, compresses it, and sends it back to the user's mobile phone.]] Opera Mini, offered free of charge, is designed primarily for [[mobile phone]]s, but also for smartphones and personal digital assistants. Versions up to 4 used the [[Java ME]] platform, requiring the mobile device to be capable of running Java ME applications. The browser began as a pilot project in 2005.{{cite press release|url=http://www.opera.com/press/releases/2005/08/10/|title=Have WAP but want WEB? Introducing Opera Mini for mobile phones|publisher=Opera Software|date=10 August 2005|accessdate=6 September 2010}} After limited releases in Europe,{{cite press release|url=http://www.opera.com/press/releases/2005/10/20/|title=Mobile comfort in the cold: Opera Mini beta now available free in the Nordics|publisher=Opera Software|date=20 October 2005|accessdate=6 September 2010}}{{cite press release|url=http://www.opera.com/press/releases/2005/11/10/|title=The full Internet for all mobile phones: Opera Mini launched in Germany|publisher=Opera Software|date=10 November 2005|accessdate=6 September 2010}} it was officially launched worldwide on 24 January 2006.{{cite journal|url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/124473/opera_officially_launches_mini_browser.html|title=Opera Officially Launches Mini Browser|last=Gohring|first=Nancy|journal=[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]|date=24 January 2006|accessdate=6 September 2010}} Opera Mini requests web pages through the Opera Software company's servers, which process and compress them before relaying the pages back to the mobile phone.{{cite press release|url=http://www.opera.com/press/releases/2006/04/06/|title=Operators making money on Opera Mini: Two million users surf 4 million Web pages every day|publisher=Opera Software|date=6 April 2006|accessdate=6 September 2010}} This compression process reduces bandwidth use by up to 90%, with a consequent speed increase,{{cite web|url=http://www.opera.com/mini/features/|title=Opera Mini Features|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=6 September 2010}} and the pre-processing smooths compatibility with web pages not designed for mobile phones.{{cite news|url=http://news.digitaltrends.com/news-article/9372/opera-mini-officially-brings-web-to-mobiles|title=Opera Mini Officially Brings Web to Mobiles|last=Duncan|first=Geoff|publisher=[[Digital Trends]]|date=24 January 2006|accessdate=6 September 2010}}{{dead link|date=August 2011}} In March 2010, Opera Software launched a new beta version of Opera Mini for mobile phones running on Google's open source Android platform.{{cite web|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/technology/2010/03/mobile-phone-opera-mini|title=Opera launches Mini 5 beta handsets which does not require Java;{{cite web|url=http://www.opera.com/mobile/download/versions/|title=Opera Mini & Opera Mobile - All mobile applications|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=15 January 2011}} it implements the same features as the Java version. On April 13, 2010, [[Opera Mini]] was officially approved as a free download for [[iPhone]] (and [[iPod Touch]]) on [[Apple Inc.|Apple]]'s [[App Store (iOS)|App Store]].{{cite press release|url=http://www.opera.com/press/releases/2010/04/13/|title=Opera Mini App approved for the App Store|date=13 April 2010|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=6 September 2010}} ===Tablets=== An iPad specific version of Opera was demonstrated at [[Mobile World Congress|Mobile World Congress 2011]],{{cite web|last=Aas|first=Aleksander|title=Opera Mini on the iPad|url=http://my.opera.com/chooseopera/blog/2011/02/16/opera-mini-on-the-ipad|publisher=[[Opera Software]]|date=16 February 2011|accessdate=23 February 2011}} and released with Opera Mini 6 for iOS on May 24, 2011.{{cite web|title=Opera Mini 6 is FINALLY available for iPhone and iPad|url=http://my.opera.com/chooseopera/blog/2011/05/24/opera-mini-6-finally-ready-for-iphone-and-ipad|publisher=[[Opera Software]]|date=24 May 2011|accessdate=21 June 2011}} An Android version of Opera for tablets is coming soon.{{cite web|last=Ãverdahl|first=Espen|title=Opera for Tablets preview|url=http://my.opera.com/chooseopera/blog/2011/01/03/opera-for-tablets-preview|publisher=[[Opera Software]]|date=3 January 2011|accessdate=23 February 2011}} No dates have yet been announced. ===Nintendo DS=== {{Main|Nintendo DS & DSi Browser}} [[File:DSOnWhite.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Nintendo DS]]]] The Nintendo DS Browser is an edition of Opera for the [[Nintendo DS]] handheld gaming system. The Nintendo DS Browser was released in Japan on 24 July 2006,{{cite press release|url=http://www.opera.com/press/releases/2006/07/24/|title=Surf in Bed: Nintendo DS Browser hits Japan|publisher=Opera Software|date=24 July 2006|accessdate=6 September 2010}} in Europe on 6 October 2006,{{cite press release|url=http://www.opera.com/press/releases/2006/10/06/|title=Nintendo DS Browser launches across Europe today|publisher=Opera Software|date=6 October 2006|accessdate=6 September 2010}} and in North America on 4 June 2007.{{cite news|url=http://www.gamespot.com/pages/news/story.php?sid=6170135&part=rss&tag=gs_news&subj=6170135|title=Original DS browser available online only|last=Sinclair|first=Brendan|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|date=4 May 2007|accessdate=6 September 2010}} It is sold as a physical [[game cartridge]] for [[US$]]30. The Nintendo DS Browser includes the same small screen rendering and page zooming technology present in Opera Mobile. It also includes [[handwriting recognition]] software and an [[on-screen keyboard]] to enable user input. Additionally, [[Nintendo]] partnered with [[Astaro]] Internet Security to provide [[web filtering]] for the Nintendo DS Browser. The technology is simply a professionally maintained [[proxy server]] that blocks web sites related to pornography, discrimination, [[Hacker (computer security)|security hacking]], [[software piracy]], violence, gambling, illegal drugs, alcohol, tobacco, [[Dating (activity)|dating]], weapons, abortion, and other content that Nintendo deems objectionable.{{cite web|url=http://www.astaro.com/ds-content-filter/|title=Astaro Parental Control for the Nintendo DS Browser|publisher=[[Astaro]]|accessdate=6 September 2010}} Users can configure the Nintendo DS Browser to receive web pages through this proxy server, and this setting can be password-protected (by a parent, for example) to prevent circumvention.{{cite web|url=http://www.nintendo.com/consumer/systems/dslite/browser.jsp#contentFilter|title=Nintendo DS Browser: Content Filtering (proxy server)|work=Customer Service|publisher=Nintendo|accessdate=6 September 2010}} In August 2007, the Nintendo DS Browser was quietly discontinued in North America,{{cite news|url=http://www.thetanooki.com/2007/08/27/nintendo-ds-browser-being-discontinued-in-north-america/ |title=Nintendo DS Browser being discontinued in North America|last=Ponte|first=Christian|publisher=The Tanooki|date=27 August 2007|accessdate=6 September 2010}} although it is still available from Nintendo's online store.{{cite web|url=http://store.nintendo.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/ProductDisplay?productId=129204¤cy=USD&catalogId=10001&tranId=0&lastAction=setCurr&storeId=10001&languageId=-1&categoryId=58694&ddkey=http://SetCurrencyPreference|title=Nintendo DS Browser (Original Style Nintendo DS)|publisher=Nintendo|accessdate=6 September 2010}} Instead, Opera is available on the [[Nintendo DSi]] through the [[DSi Shop]], and pre-installed on newer devices.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}} ===Wii=== {{Main|Internet Channel}} [[File:Wii Wiimotew.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Nintendo's [[Wii]] console]] On 10 May 2006, the Opera Software company announced that it was partnering with [[Nintendo]] to provide a web browser for Nintendo's [[Wii]] gaming console. Opera for the Wii, called the [[Internet Channel]], was free to download from its release on 12 April 2007 until 30 June 2007. After that date, Wii users had to pay 500 [[Wii Points]] ([[US$]]5{{Clarify|The price for 500 points depends on the country of the console (and for European consoles on the country setting). For example, in Japan 500 points cost 500 yen, or approximately US$6.50.|date=August 2011}}) to download it. However, in late August / early September of the year 2009, the Internet Channel was once again available to download for free and those who paid for the service had their Wii Points returned in the form of a free NES virtual console game. Scott Hedrick, an executive of the Opera Software company, explained that the Wii browser was designed to suit a "living room environment".{{cite web|last=Temperton|first=James|url=http://www.cubed3.com/news/5329|title=Interview: Opera's Nintendo Wii Browser|date=3 June 2006|accessdate=6 September 2010|publisher=Cubed3}} In contrast to Opera's appearance on computer monitors, fonts are larger and the interface is simplified for easier use. Notwithstanding the changes in design, the Wii browser supports the same web standards as the desktop version of Opera 9, including passing the [[Acid2]] test.{{cite web|url=http://operawatch.com/news/2006/12/wii-browser-passes-the-acid2-test.html|title=Wii browser passes the Acid2 test|last=Goldman|first=Daniel|publisher=Opera Watch|date=22 December Software|date=28 June 2011|accessdate=11 August 2011}} Since its first release in 1996, the browser has had limited success on personal computers. It has had more success in the area of mobile browsing, with product releases for a variety of platforms.{{cite web|url=http://arstechnica.com/microsoft/news/2007/05/microsofts-silverlight-to-get-opera.ars|title=Microsoft's Silverlight to get Opera compatibility|last=Reimer|first=Jeremy|publisher=Ars Technica|date=10 May 2007|accessdate=6 September 2010}} Approximately 40 million mobile phones have shipped with a copy of Opera pre-installed.{{cite web|url=http://www.net-security.org/article.php?id=1052|title=Interview with Christen Krogh, Opera Software's VP of Engineering|last=Zorz|first=Mirko|date=13 August 2007|publisher=net-security.org|accessdate=6 September 2010}} It is used on some television [[set-top box]]es as well.{{cite web|url=http://www.opera.com/business/solutions/devices/gallery/|title=Opera Solutions|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=6 September 2010}}{{dead link|date=August 2011}} In 2005, [[Adobe Systems]] opted to integrate Opera's [[layout engine]], [[Presto (layout engine)|Presto]], into its [[Adobe Creative Suite]] applications. Because of this issue, Opera 8.01 and higher have included workarounds to help certain popular but problematic web sites display properly, but website compatibility is still perceived by some as a significant issue in more recent versions.{{cite web|url=http://www.opera.com/docs/browserjs/|title=Browser JavaScript Explained|publisher=Opera Software|accessdate=6 September 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.opera.com/docs/changelogs/windows/801/|title=Changelog for Opera 8.01 for Windows|publisher=Opera Software|date=16 June 2005|accessdate=6 September 2010}}
